metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Exposure to greenspaces could reduce the high global burden of pain

abstract.text: Please cite this article as: Stanhope, J., Breed, M.F., Weinstein, P., Exposure to greenspaces could reduce the high global burden of pain, Environmental Research, https://doi.
Painful conditions are among the leading causes of years lived with disability. To 27 reduce this burden, novel, cost-effective and accessible interventions are required. 28

We propose that greenspace exposure may be one such intervention. Drawing on 29 evidence from neuroscience, physiology, microbiology, and psychology, we 30 articulate how and why exposure to greenspaces could improve pain outcomes and 31 reduce the high global burden of pain. Greenspace exposure potentially provides 32 opportunities to benefit from known or proposed health-enhancing components of 33 nature, such as environmental microbiomes, phytoncides, negative air ions, sunlight, 34 and the sights and sounds of nature itself. We review the established and potential 35 links between these specific exposures and pain outcomes. While further research is 36 required to determine possible causal links between greenspace exposure and pain 37 outcomes, we suggest that there is already sufficient evidence to help reduce the 38 global burden of pain by improving access and exposure to quality greenspaces. 39 40

body_text.text: . Characteristics for the three main pain categories 103

Pain category Characteristics Nociceptive pain Involves the stimulation of nociceptors (the peripheral nerve terminals that detect noxious stimuli, which may be mechanical, chemical or thermal) ( Nocipathic/ nociplastic/ algopathic pain Also described as 'dysfunctional pain' (Nagakura, 2015) Occurs in the absence of tissue threat or damage, and without Pain modulation may also be influenced by pro-inflammatory mediators, nerve 127 growth factor, hormones (e.g. endorphins), and epigenetic modifications, and 128 involves immune cells, mast cells, macrophages, and leukocytes (Guo et al., 2019) . 129

Particularly in the acute phase, pain management may target nociception, including 141 any underlying inflammation. In the acute phase, strategies to prevent the transition 142 from acute to chronic pain may also be implemented, targeting any of the risk factors 143 (Table 2) . These factors may continue to be targeted in chronic pain management, 144

although treatments aimed at reducing hypersensitivity may be added. Finally, 145 surgical options may be considered to address underlying problems (e.g. joint 146 replacement, spinal fusion, nerve decompression), as well as strategies to reduce 147 hypersensitivity. Chronic pain treatment is typically multidisciplinary and may be 148 pain, or discomfort are generally used as proxy-measures of musculoskeletal 189 disorders (Kuorinka et al., 1987) , indicating that these symptoms can be 190 pathognomonic of musculoskeletal disorders and that people diagnosed with 191 musculoskeletal conditions are therefore likely to have been experienced pain. 192

However, one of the limitations of this study was that the patients with 193 musculoskeletal complaints studied might not necessarily present with pain. In the following sections, we explore the biological plausibility of greenspace 234 exposure per se leading to an improvement in pain outcomes (see conceptual model 235

in Figure 1 ). These sections refer to the particular components of nature that 236 greenspace exposure may provide, and we separately discuss those that are 237 specific to greenspace (e.g. environmental microbiota, phytoncides, sights and 238 sounds of greenspace) from those that are not greenspace-specific but are facilitated 239 by greenspace exposure (e.g. sunlight, social integration and cohesion (Jennings 240 and Bamkole, 2019), and physical activity (Keskinen et al., 2018) . We detail how 241 these greenspace components could be linked to pain outcomes via various Phytoncides may also influence the human immune system, particularly natural killer 414 cell function. In vitro studies have shown that phytoncides can enhance human 415 natural killer cell function (Li et al., 2006) . Natural killer cell function was enhanced 416 for people walking in forests, but not in cities, and importantly phytoncides were only 417 detected in the forest and not in the city (Li et al., 2008) . This study did not, however, 418 account for the potential impact of other forest exposures (e.g. environmental 419 microbiome) that may have influenced the relationship. Nonetheless, greenspace 420 exposure appears to improve natural killer cell activity, and natural killer cells have 421 recently been proposed as a treatment for some types of pain (Davies et al., 2019) . forces of water, sunlight, atmospheric radiant or cosmic rays, and natural and 441 artificial corona discharge (Jiang et al., 2018) . They are less prevalent in urban 442 settings compared with forests, places with moving water, and mountainous areas 443 (Mao et al., 2012) . There is some, albeit limited, evidence of negative air ion 444 exposure altering pain outcomes (David et al., 1960; Minehart et al., 1961; 445 Olivereau, 1970) , through a range of potential effects on humans and other animals. potentially pain perception through that mechanism as well. We therefore suggest 525 that greenspace exposure is likely to decrease both pain perception, and the 526 transition from acute to chronic pain, via improvements in social integration and 527 support. 528

Here we argue that exposure to greenspace may be an effective, safe and 531 accessible strategy to help alleviate the global burden of pain. With the exception of 532 those with compromised immune systems, exposure to greenspace should therefore 533 be encouraged for those experiencing pain. 534

The association and potential therapeutic benefit of greenspace exposure for those 536 with pain should be further explored, with a particular focus on the transition from 537 acute to chronic pain, and the prevalence and burden of chronic pain. To do this we 538 need valid and reliable measures of exposure to greenspace (e.g. time spent in 539 greenspace, characteristics of the greenspace), which, to our knowledge, do not 540 currently exist. 541

One of the advantages of greenspace exposure as an intervention for pain, 543 particularly chronic pain, is that it is not reliant on medical intervention, and could be 544 situation, strict lockdowns in countries like Italy are likely to reduce greenspace 561 exposure for many people. These barriers support the need to optimise opportunistic 562 encounters with greenspace, such as advice to optimise private greenspaces to 563 maximize benefits, as well as utilising verges and high-use areas (e.g. commuter 564

paths, work place environments) for optimal greenspace, so that passive exposure to 565 the aerobiome is achieved. Stakeholder engagement is also essential to improve 566 usage of public greenspaces (Roberts et al., 2016) . 567

To optimise greenspaces to improve pain outcomes we need to understand which 569 elements of greenspace have the most influence on pain outcomes (e.g. 570 phytoncides, microbiome), what the most advantageous greenspaces comprise of 571 (e.g. the specific microbes that should be in relative abundance), and how to 572 encourage people, particularly those in pain, into such greenspaces. 573

With specific reference to the environmental microbiome, further work is required to 575 characterise the components of the environmental microbiome that directly influence 576 pain. Such health outcome-environmental microbiome association studies have 577 begun in non-pain related areas (e.g. anxiety-like behaviour; (Liddicoat et al., 2020) , 578

and are a required precursor to not only understanding the level of exposure to these 579 potential pain-mitigating microbiota from greenspaces, but also how to derive these 580 pain management benefits via targeted changes to greenspaces. 581 582 CONCLUSIONS 583

Here we articulate how and why exposure to greenspaces is likely to reduce pain, 584 particularly chronic pain. Greenspaces provide exposure to environmental 585 microbiomes, phytoncides, negative air ions, natural sights and sounds, and sunlight, 586 and may facilitate physical activity and social integration. We describe established or 587 potential links between these specific exposures and pain outcomes. Further 588 research is required to determine the mechanistic pathways that link greenspace and 589 pain outcomes, as well as the nature and duration of specific exposures relevant to 590 optimising pain outcomes. By making available public and private greenspaces 591 accordingly, and reducing barriers to access, we are likely to see a reduction in the 592 global burden of pain. 593 594 595
The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any 597 commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential 598 competing or conflict of interest.

FIGREF0.text: Hainline et al., 2017; Loeser and Treede, 2008) Includes inflammatory pain (Loeser and Treede, 2008) Protective mechanism -the body's 'first detection' system (Hainline et al., 2017; Loeser and Treede, 2008) Activation of nociceptors does not necessarily result in pain (Hainline et al., 2017) The relationship between nociceptor activity and the pain experience is not linear (Hainline et al., 2017) Neuropathic pain Involves a lesion of the somatosensory nervous system (International Association for the Study of Pain (IASP), 2017; Kosek et al., 2016; Loeser and Treede, 2008) May result from trauma or disease (Vardeh et al., 2016), or repetitive mechanical loading or inflammatory irritation of the peripheral nerves (Hainline et al., 2017)

FIGREF1.text: somatosensory nervous system lesions (Kosek et al., 2016) Pain may occur through altered nociceptive pathway function, pathological changes of nociception, or central sensitisation (Hainline et al., 2017; Kosek et al., 2016) which occurs when the central nervous system nociceptors become hypersensitive (Loeser and Treede, 2008) Thought to be the pain type associated with visceral pain disorders, fibromyalgia and Complex Region Pain Syndrome Type 1 (Kosek et al., 2016) 104 factors (Bushnell et al., 2013), and contextual cues (Moseley and Arntz, 2007). Pain 118 modulation occurs through anatomical or functional neurological changes (Hainline 119 et al., 2017), and/or through various processes of the peripheral and central nervous 120 systems (Bushnell et al., 2013). 121 122 There are several neural factors potentially involved in the experience of pain. These 123 neural factors include the activation of nociceptors (that detect noxious stimuli; 124 (Hainline et al., 2017; Loeser and Treede, 2008), and the descending pathways (that 125 influence pain at the dorsal horn of the spinal cord; (Guo et al., 2019; Zhuo, 2017).

FIGREF3.text: second relevant study,Ihlebaek et al. (2018) investigated the association 196 between the degree of "vegetation cover greenness" and land use greenness within 197 the participants' residential 'circuit', and whether the participant reported pain and/or 198 stiffness in their muscles/joints in the last four weeks in three or more (of six) body 199 regions (although the body regions were not listed). No association between 200 greenspace and pain for males was observed, but for females the prevalence of 201 pain/stiffness was higher in those living in areas with more vegetation cover 202 greenness and land use greenness(Ihlebaek et al., 2018). This unexpected finding 203 should be interpreted with caution given a number of limitations. Firstly, the outcome 204 measures employed were not tested for validity and reliability, and secondly there 205 was no differentiation between pain and stiffness.206 207 In both studies (Ihlebaek et al., 2018; Maas et al., 2009), the use of residential 208 proximity to greenspace does not necessarily provide an accurate measure of a 209 resident's greenspace exposure, owing to individual differences in exposure to 210 greenspace. 211 212 We do however have additional corroborative evidence suggesting that a 213 relationship is likely, and that further research in the area is worthwhile. There is 214 evidence for example that forest therapy (Han et al., 2016; Kang et al., 2015), 215 exercise in green areas (Huber et al., 2019) (not to be confused with 'green 216 prescriptions' that refer to written advice to a patient regarding physical activity made 217 by a health professional; (New Zealand Ministry of Health, 2016), and involvement in 218 horticultural therapy (Kim et al., 2006; Verra et al., 2012) and conservation (Moore et 219 al., 2007) are associated with better pain outcomes. However, these studies have 220 not been designed with appropriate controls to ascertain whether greenspace 221 exposure itself led to the benefits or whether these benefits could be due to other 222 aspects, such as physical activity and/or social interaction. Furthermore, all used 223 lower level study designs (National Health and Medical Research Council, 2009; 224 Oxford Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine, 2011) (e.g. observational studies), and 225 some studies of forest therapy and green exercise actually also included 226 interventions (e.g. walking/hiking (Han et al., 2016; Huber et al., 2019; Kang et al., 227 2015), being residential (Han et al., 2016; Huber et al., 2019), music therapy (Han et 228 al., 2016) which were not provided to the comparison groups. As it stands, there is 229 therefore some suggestion that greenspace exposure may assist in pain 230 management, however the evidence to date is insufficient to determine whether the 231 benefits are due to greenspace exposure per se. 232 233

FIGREF4.text: 242 ecophysiological linkage mechanisms, some mechanisms of which are known, but 243 including others that are not. Not represented in the conceptual model are additional 244 intrinsic linkages within the ecophysiological linkage mechanisms, such as the 245 influence of gut microbiome on mental health (Liu et al., 2019; Vaghef-Mehrabany et 246 al., 2019; Yang et al., 2019). These added layers of complexity and unknowns must 247 remain as open questions and are not discussed further in our study.248

FIGREF5.text: Conceptual model linking greenspace exposure to pain outcomes. Not 250 shown are additional potential pathways joining different ecophysiological linkage 251 mechanisms. 252 253 Environmental microbiomes 254The 'old friends' hypothesis proposes that humans evolved alongside a diverse suite 255 of environmental microbiota (collectively known as 'microbiomes'), and that co-256 evolved symbiotic relationships developed(Rook et al., 2004). This co-evolution 257 underpins our argument that exposure to greenspace (with its microbiome) may 258 positively influence pain outcomes. It has recently been demonstrated that direct soil 259 contact changes the human skin microbiome(Grönroos et al., 2019), and that 260 exposure to different environments (and their respective microbiomes) changes the 261 human nasal and skin microbiome(Lai et al., 2017). Importantly, the latter study was 262 conducted indoors and is therefore not susceptible to some of the potential 263 confounding exposures present outdoors (e.g. direct plant/soil/animal interactions, 264 exposure to sunlight and phytoncides) that may also influence the human 265 microbiome (as discussed below). The influence of the environmental microbiome on 266 the human gut microbiome is not currently well understood(Blum et  al., 2019; 267 Tasnim et al., 2017), however animal studies indicate such an influence (Blum et al., 268 2019), even via indirect exposure to soil via the aerobiome only (Liddicoat et al.microbiome-gut-brain axis refers to the bidirectional communication between the 272 gut microbiome, the gut and the brain, mediated by neurotransmitters, bacterial 273 metabolites, cytokines, hormones and neural communication (Kelly et al., 2015; 274 Mayer et al., 2014). Interest in the microbiome-gut-brain axis has increased 275 dramatically since 2009, with over 500 papers published on the topic in 2018 alone 276 (Zyoud et al., 2019). However, pain as an outcome has been relatively under-277 investigated, with studies predominantly focusing on visceral pain (Guo et al., 2019; 278 Rea et al., 2019). The relationship between the human microbiome and pain 279 outcomes has recently been comprehensively reviewed (Guo et al., 2019; Rea et al., 280 2019), hence we provide only a summary of the current evidence base, with 281 interested readers referred to Guo et al. (2019) and Rea et al. (2019) for further 282 detail. 283 284 Associations between the human microbiome and a range of painful conditions have 285 been reported. These conditions include endometriosis (Leonardi et al., 2019), 286 fibromyalgia (Malatji et al., 2017), myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue 287 syndrome (Nagy-Szakal et al., 2017), interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome 288 (Nickel et al., 2019), chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (Shoskes et al., 289 2016), dermatitis (Gulliver et al., 2018), and inflammatory bowel disease (Knights et 290 al., 2013). Furthermore, there is emerging experimental evidence that changing the 291 gut microbiome through probiotics (Lactobacillus casei Shirota (Lei et al., 2017), L. 292 gasseri OLL2809 (Itoh et al., 2011), and combined L. acidophilus, L. plantarum, L. 293 fermentum and L. gasseri (Khodaverdi et al., 2019) reduces pain in people with knee 294 osteoarthritis (Lei et al., 2017), and endometriosis (Itoh et al., 2011; Khodaverdi et 295 al., 2019). Recently, faecal microbiota transplants have also been shown to reduce 296 pain in those with fibromyalgia (Thurm et al., 2017) and Clostridium difficile infection 297 (Alukal et al., 2019). Although these positive results could be due either to changes 298 in the disease state or to changes in pain processing, they nonetheless suggest that 299 exposure to greenspace -and their associated environmental microbiomes -may 300 lead to reductions in pain, via changes in the human microbiome. 301 302 A recent study by Shiro et al. (2017) reported an association between stool 303 consistency (a proxy measure of the gut microbiome) and pain intensity (initiated by 304 mechanical stimulation of the inter-digital space between the second and third, and 305 the fourth-fifth digits of the right hand). This study provides some evidence of the 306 potential role of gut microbiome on pain perception, although the causal mechanisms 307 are still hypothetical. 308 309 As outlined above, the gut microbiome can influence the brain via various 310 microbially-mediated mechanisms, and those related to chronic pain have recently 311 been reviewed elsewhere (Guo et al., 2019). Microbiota-derived mediators may 312 decrease pain perception via peripheral and central mechanisms. For peripheral 313 mechanisms, the mediators that reduce hypersensitivity include proteases, kynurenic 314 acid, and GABA (Guo et al., 2019). Short-chain fatty acids regulate leucocyte 315 functions, and one of these short-chain fatty acids, butyrate, reduces pain associated 316 with nerve injury by inhibiting histone deacetylase (Guo et al., 2019). Bile acids are 317 another type of mediator, that may reduce pain by activating release of endogenous 318 opioids from macrophages (Guo et al., 2019). The bacteria that could be implicated 319 in the production of the abovementioned mediators include L. rhamnosus 320 (Pokusaeva et al., 2017; Siragusa et al., 2007), L. brevis (Barrett et al., 2012), L. 321 buchneri (Cho et al., 2007), L. paracasei (Komatsuzaki et al., 2005), L. plantarum 322 (Siragusa et al., 2007), L. delbruekii subsp. bulgaricus (Siragusa et al., 2007), 323 Monascus purpureus (Su et al., 2003), Streptococcus salivarius subsp. thermophilus 324 (Yang et al., 2008), Clostridium butyricum (Liu et al., 2015; Rivière et al., 2016), 325 Coprococcus eutactus (Rivière et al., 2016), C. comes (Rivière et al., 2016), 326 Bifidobacterium spp. (Rivière et al., 2016), B. dentium (Barrett et al., 2012; 327 Pokusaeva et al., 2017), B. infantis (Barrett et al., 2012), B. adolescentis (Barrett et 328 al., 2012), Bacteroides fragilis (Strandwitz et al., 2019), Parabacteroides spp. 329 (Strandwitz et al., 2019), Faecalibacterium prausnitzii (Rivière et al., 2016), 330 Eubacterium hallii (Rivière et al., 2016), E. rectale (Rivière et al., 2016), 331 Anaerostripes butyraticus (Rivière et al., 2016), A. caccae (Rivière et al., 2016), A. 332 hadrus (Rivière et al., 2016), Butyricicoccus pullicaecorum (Rivière et al., 2016), 333 Roseburia faecis (Rivière et al., 2016), R. inulinivorans (Rivière et al., 2016), R. 334 intestinalis (Rivière et al., 2016), R. hominis (Rivière et al., 2016), and Escherichia 335 spp. (Strandwitz et al., 2019) again supporting a potential association between gut 336 microbiome and pain outcomes. 337 338 For central mechanisms, central sensitisation may be the result of glial activation 339 which ultimately leads to decreased GABAergic synaptic neurotransmission and/or 340 elevated glutamatergic synaptic neurotransmission, and the gut microbiome plays a 341 role in microglial function, maturation and morphology (Guo et al., 2019). There is 342 however no direct evidence, to our knowledge, linking the gut microbiome to central 343 sensitisation, although GABA-producing bacteria could theoretically be implicated. 344 345 In addition to the abovementioned mechanisms linking the human microbiome and 346 pain outcomes, the human microbiome influences mental health outcomes. 347 Probiotics (e.g. Lactobaccilis spp., Bacillus spp., Clostridium spp., Bifidobacterium 348 spp.) can reduce anxiety (Liu et al., 2019) and depression (Liu et al., 2019; Vaghef-349 Mehrabany et al., 2019), and gut microbiome regulation (e.g. probiotics, dietary 350 changes) can reduce anxiety (Yang et al., 2019). There is also an association 351 between gut microbiome and sleep (Smith et al., 2019). Experimental sleep 352 deprivation has been shown to influence the gut microbiome (Benedict et al., 2016; 353 Poroyko et al., 2016), however to our knowledge no study has investigated whether 354 changes to the microbiome influence sleep outcomes. By improving mental health 355 and potentially sleep, due to the changes in gut microbiome, greenspace exposure 356 may improve pain outcomes. 357 358 It has recently been demonstrated in a mouse study that a diverse gut microbiome is 359 required for fear extinction learning to occur (Chu et al., 2019), which may have 360 implications for chronic pain. There is some evidence to suggest that people with 361 chronic pain have reduced differential learning (Harvie et al., 2017), and that fear-362 avoidance beliefs (Drake et al., 2018; Hruschak and Cochran, 2018; Jayakumar et 363 al., 2018; Morton et al., 2019) are associated with chronic pain. Chu et al.'s (2019) 364 suggested that interventions to reduce fear-avoidance (e.g. graded exposure) may 365 have had limited success in those with lower gut microbiome diversity. These 366 findings may also have implications for changing other cognitive elements of the pain 367 experience such as pain beliefs, expectations regarding pain and recovery. 368 369 Although the association between environmental microbiome and pain outcomes has 370 not been investigated, we suggest that such an association is likely to exist owing to 371 the influence of environmental microbiomes on human microbiomes, and the 372 existence of multiple potential pathways linking the human microbiome and pain 373 outcomes. 374 375 Sights and sounds of nature 376 The biophilia hypothesis -where humans have an innate and natural affiliation with 377 nature (Wilson, 1986) -has traditionally been central to the proposed link between 378 greenspace exposure and health outcomes, and relates to exposure to the sights 379 and sounds of nature. Listening to pleasant nature sounds during elective 380 Caesarean section has been shown to reduce post-operative pain severity 381 (Farzaneh et al., 2019), and also resulted in lower pain for those undergoing 382 mechanical ventilation (Saadatmand et al., 2015). Combined natural sounds and 383 sights have resulted in lower pain severity compared with both city sounds and 384 sights and with a control during bone marrow aspirate and biopsy (Lechtzin et al., 385 2010). Vincent et al. (2010) demonstrated differences in the effect of viewing an 386 array of natural scenery on experimental pain sensation. They found that the 387 combined prospect/refuge scenery resulted in lower pain sensation than prospect, 388 refuge and hazard scenery and the control (a black screen). Listening to pleasant 389 nature sounds has also been reported to improve sleep (Nasari et al., 2018), while a 390 virtual nature experience reduced stress (Liszio et al., 2018), which may also lead to 391 a reduction in pain. Greenspace exposure could therefore result in a reduction in 392 pain due to exposure to natural sights and sounds. 393 394 Phytoncides 395The antimicrobial volatile organic compounds emitted as a defence mechanism by 396 plants are called phytoncides, and they permeate the air particularly in or near 397 greenspace(Franco et al., 2017). To our knowledge no study has investigated the 398 relationship between phytoncides and pain in humans, however an analgesic effect 399 has been reported for mice(Cheng et al., 2009).400 401 Given their antimicrobial properties (Franco et al., 2017), phytoncides may also 402 influence the microbiome. To our knowledge, the impact of phytoncides exposure on 403 the microbiome has not been examined, however the effect of dietary phytoncide 404 supplements on gut Lactobacillus spp. and Escherichia coli counts has (Kim et al., 405 2018a; Li et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2012). These studies of livestock found that 406 dietary phytoncides supplements reported mixed results, with one study reporting no 407 change (Zhang et al., 2018), and others reporting a significantly higher Lactobacillus 408 spp. counts (Kim et al., 2018a; Li et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2012) and lower 409 Escherichia coli counts (Kim et al., 2018a; Li et al., 2015) with the supplements. 410 These alternations to the gut microbiome may influence pain perception, due to the 411 mechanisms outlined above. 412 413

FIGREF6.text: also been shown to improve sleep and reduce anxiety in animal 424 studies (Cheng et al., 2009), providing further evidence of a potential link between 425 greenspace exposure, phytoncides, and pain outcomes. Different anxiety responses 426 have been observed with exposure to different tree species in forest bathing (Guan 427 et al., 2017), which could be explained by differences in the phytoncides released. A 428 recent random crossover study (Horiuchi et al., 2014) compared two forest bathing 429 exposures; one where participants could see the forest and the other where they 430 could not. There was a significant reduction in trait-anxiety, depression, confusion 431 and fatigue when the forest could be viewed, but not when the view was occluded, 432 however there were no significant differences in the outcomes between the two 433 exposures post-exposure (Horiuchi et al., 2014). Horiuchi et al.(2014) indicated that 434 phytoncides are unlikely to be the sole reason for changes in human health 435 outcomes related to greenspace exposure, but supported the notion that greenspace 436 exposure may improve pain outcomes. 437 438 Negative air ions 439 Negative air ions are generated by plants (see Jiang et al. (2018) for a list), shear 440

FIGREF7.text: 446 These effects include decreased cyclic nucleotides, lower dopamine, activation of 447 natural killer cells, and improved mental health (Jiang et al., 2018), all of which may 448 reduce pain, including chronic pain (Davies et al., 2019; Drake et al., 2018; Hruschak 449 and Cochran, 2018; Jayakumar et al., 2018; Li et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2018; Taylor et 450 al., 2016). 451 452 Negative air ions have also been shown to kill or reduce a range of microbes, 453 including Serratia marcescens, Staphylococcus albus, S. aureus, S. epidermidis, 454 Pseudomonas veronii, P. fluorescens, Salmonella Enteritidis, Candida albicans, 455 Escherichia coli, and Penicillum notatum, and have been shown to prevent 456 Acinetobacter infections (Jiang et al., 2018). These antimicrobial effects indicate that 457 negative air ions have the potential to alter the human microbiome, which may 458 therefore influence pain outcomes. 459 460 Sunlight exposure 461Sunlight exposure is the first of three generic factors that we propose may link 462 greenspace exposure to pain outcomes. Depending on the weather, geographic 463 location, canopy cover and time of day, spending time in greenspace is likely to lead 464 to sunlight exposure. Sunlight exposure is perhaps most commonly associated with 465 vitamin D production, but exposure to sunlight also leads to the production of beta-466 endorphin (an endogenous opioid peptide), melatonin, and nitric oxide (a 467 vasodilator), as well as the release of carbon monoxide from haemoglobin (a 468 vasodilator), and expression of the proopiomelanocortin gene (which results in the 469 production of beta-endorphin and cortisol)(Holick, 2016).470 471 Observational studies have identified an association between vitamin D levels and 472 arthritis, muscle pain, chronic widespread pain (Wu et al., 2018), and low back pain 473 (Zadro et al., 2017); however, studies investigating the impact of vitamin D 474 supplementation on pain outcomes have generally shown that vitamin D 475 supplementation is no better than placebo for people with lower back pain (Zadro et 476 al., 2018) and non-specific musculoskeletal disorders (Gaikwad et al., 2017). 477 However, there is some evidence of vitamin D lowering pain intensity for those with 478 chronic widespread pain (Yong et al., 2017). The discrepancy between the 479 observational and experimental evidence regarding the relationship vitamin D and 480 pain may be the result of vitamin D acting as a proxy-measure of sunlight exposure. 481 Sunlight exposure could lead to a change in pain through non-vitamin D pathways, 482 including the release of beta-endorphins (Holick, 2016) and melatonin (Zhu et al., 483 2017), or indeed changes in the microbiome (Waterhouse et al., 2019). Furthermore, 484 sunlight exposure (Düzgün and Durmaz Akyol, 2017) and vitamin D supplementation 485 (Jamilian et al., 2019) have led to improved sleep including for people with chronic 486 pain specifically (Huang et al., 2013). Vitamin D supplementation has also resulted in 487 reduced inflammation (Jamilian et al., 2019) and improvements in depression 488 (Jamilian et al., 2019), which may in turn contribute to improved pain outcomes. 489 490 Physical activity 491 Exposure to greenspace reportedly facilitates physical activity (Keskinen et al., 492 2018); the second generic factor in our review. Physical activity is commonly 493 prescribed by health professionals, particularly for patients in pain. Evidence in 494 support of physical activity for reducing the prevalence and impact of pain include 495 findings of physical activity being associated with a lower incidence of neck pain 496 (Kim et al., 2018b), and lower prevalence of lower back pain (Alzahrani et al., 497 2019b), including frequent and chronic lower back pain (Shiri and Falah-Hassani, 498 2017). Furthermore, interventions to increase incidental physical activity lead to 499 improved lower back pain-related disability (Alzahrani et al., 2019a). For those with 500 musculoskeletal conditions in particular, physical activity may decrease nociception 501 by improving the underlying musculoskeletal condition. Exercise reduces 502 inflammation (Stigger et al., 2019; Zheng et al., 2019) and stress (Bischoff et al., 503 2019; Rodriguez-Ayllon et al., 2019), improves sleep (Banno et al., 2018; Kreutz et 504 al., 2019; Lederman et al., 2019; Lowe et al., 2019; Stutz et al., 2019) and mental 505 health (Béland et al., 2019; McDowell et al., 2019; Morres et al., 2019; Nakamura et 506 al., 2019; Rodriguez-Ayllon et al., 2019), and changes the human microbiome 507 (Mailing et al., 2019). The health improvements associated with exercise may also 508 influence pain perception and the risk of transitioning from acute to chronic pain. 509 Thus, physical activity, particularly when facilitated by greenspace exposure, is likely 510 to also contribute to a reduction in the global burden of pain. 511 512 Social integration 513 Although social integration is not specific to greenspace, greenspace exposure is 514 associated with a range of social benefits and has been identified as a facilitator of 515 social integration and cohesion (Jennings and Bamkole, 2019), and would therefore 516 be expected to improve social support. Social support has been associated with pain 517 perception (Che et al., 2018b), including experimental pain (Che et al., 2018a), while 518 low levels of social support are associated with a higher risk of transitioning from 519 acute to chronic pain (Fregoso et al., 2019). In addition, higher levels of social 520 support and integration are associated with lower inflammation (Uchino et al., 2018), 521 better sleep (Kent de Grey et al., 2018), and better mental health (Tengku Moud et 522 al., 2019) which may all in turn influence pain perception. Of note, sleep may also 523 influence the gut microbiome (Benedict et al., 2016; Poroyko et al., 2016) and thus 524

FIGREF8.text: implemented while on waiting lists for specialist appointments -a particularly 545 important consideration in the socially isolating conditions of a pandemic, with 546 elective surgery and pain clinics closed down. It can take years for patients to gain 547 access to these services (Anderson, 2016), during which time their nervous systems 548 change and the burden of their pain increases. The caveat to this is, however, that 549 appropriate greenspaces must be accessible to those who require them. Several550 general barriers to such greenspace access have been suggested, and include a 551 lack of amenities (Cronin-de-Chavez et al., 2019; Sefcik et al., 2019), safety 552 concerns (Boyd et al., 2018; Cronin-de-Chavez et al., 2019; Sefcik et al., 2019; 553 Selby et al., 2019), proximity to greenspace (Selby et al., 2019), and issues with 554 transport (Boyd et al., 2018; Cronin-de-Chavez et al., 2019; Fretwell and Greig, 555 2019; Sefcik et al., 2019). Perhaps more importantly, a lack of interest (Boyd et al., 556 2018; Fretwell and Greig, 2019) and time (Boyd et al., 2018; Fretwell and Greig, 557 2019; Holt et al., 2019; Selby et al., 2019), and debilitating health conditions (Boyd et 558 al., 2018; Cronin-de-Chavez et al., 2019; Fretwell and Greig, 2019; Sefcik et al., 559 2019) have also been identified as barriers. Finally, in the current COVID-19 560

TABREF0.text: by a range of health professionals including physiotherapists, 149psychologists, occupational therapists, dentists, podiatrists, general practitioners, 150 pain physicians, neurologists, anaesthetists, and appropriate surgeons (e.g. 151The treatment of chronic pain can be complex, resource intensive, and have varying 154 levels of success. Novel treatments to reduce the risk of transition from acute to 155 chronic pain and to treat chronic pain itself are both required. These treatments need 156 to be accessible in a timely manner, acceptable to the patient, safe, and cost-157 effective. While existing strategies contribute to managing pain, new strategies to 158 manage pain should be explored to reduce the global burden further. Recent work 159 on greenspace may provide an appropriate option to help reduce the high global 160 burden of pain, particularly chronic pain. • Analgesics (Fregoso et al., 2019; Nisbet and Sehgal, 2019) • Anti-inflammatory medications (Fregoso et al., 2019; Nisbet Graded exposure (López-de-Uralde-Villanueva et al., 2016) Reduce hypersensitivity • Antidepressants (to modulate the opioid system) (Nisbet and Sehgal, 2019) • Anticonvulsants (to increases gamma-aminobutyric acid levels in the brain) (Fregoso et al., 2019; Nisbet and Sehgal, 2019) • Electrophysical agents (Binny et al., 2019; Hofmeister et al., 2019) COULD EXPOSURE TO GREENSPACE HELP REDUCE THE PAIN BURDEN? 166 Greenspace exposure has been associated with a range of positive health 167 outcomes, including conditions associated with pain (e.g. lower stress levels, and 168 better mental health; (Twohig-Bennett and Jones, 2018), providing some indication 169 that greenspace exposure may have a beneficial impact on pain. Despite this, the 170 relationship between greenspace and pain outcomes or painful conditions (e.g. 171 musculoskeletal disorders) have not been adequately investigated (Twohig-Bennett 172 To our knowledge, only two studies (Ihlebaek et al., 2018; Maas et al., 2009) have 175 investigated the possible association between greenspace exposure and pain 176 outcomes, with mixed findings. Maas et al. (2009) investigated the relationship 177 between the percentage of greenspace in circles with 1 or 3 kilometre radii around 178 the participants' places of residence, and health conditions reported in general 179 practice notes in the 12 months prior. The health conditions targeted included 180 musculoskeletal conditions such as neck/back complaints, severe back complaints, 181 severe neck/back complaints, severe elbow/wrist/hand complaints, osteoarthritis, 182 and arthritis (Maas et al., 2009). Of these musculoskeletal conditions, there was a 183 significant negative association between the percentage of greenspace in the 1 km 184 radius circle and the number of neck/back complaints, severe back complaints, 185 severe neck/back complaints, severe elbow/wrist/hand complaints (Maas et al., 186 2009). No such significant association was found for the 3 km radius (Maas et al., 187 2009). The study is directly relevant to the question we are asking, because ache, 188
